p: Speleothem δ 18O can, under certain conditions, be a good proxy for hydro-climatic change. Drip water δ 18O, which reflects the isotopic composition of infiltrating meteoric water, in combination with processes occurring during percolation, controls speleothem δ 18O [ 50]. A number of processes that relate to the climate-system control precipitation δ 18O, including precipitation amount and seasonality, moisture source and transport distance, as well as condensation temperature [ 51]. Further processes in the atmosphere, such as the proportions of low-intensity stratiform vs high-intensity convective precipitation, altitudinal transportation of raindrops within rainfall systems, and evaporation below the cloud base, have also been shown to affect δ 18O in precipitation, highlighting the complex nature of δ 18O values in meteoric waters [ 52, 53].
